answers.author: Pamela Muse
answers.text:
Amanda – I hope the following is helpful:
Seattle, WA - Street Furniture, Public Art and Unique Objects in the Public Right-of-Way 
http://www.seattle.gov/transportation/rowmanual/manual/4_26.asp
Santa Rosa, CA - Downtown Street Furnishings Palette
http://ci.santa-rosa.ca.us/departments/economicdev/downtown/Pages/palettes.aspx 
Trash can placement – go down to “Location of Trash Cans”
http://www.sfbetterstreets.org/find-project-types/streetscape-elements/street-furniture-overview/sidewalk-trashcans/ 
Street Furniture Overview
http://www.sfbetterstreets.org/find-project-types/streetscape-elements/street-furniture-overview/ 
Street Furniture/Walking Environment
http://safety.fhwa.dot.gov/saferjourney/library/countermeasures/02.htm 
Pedestrian Facilities Design Guidance
http://www.csrardc.org/bike/bikeped/engineer_ped_fac.html 
Principles and guidance for the design of a thoroughfare's streetside and the specific elements that comprise the streetside
http://www.ite.org/css/online/DWUT08.html 
Pam
Pamela Muse
Western Regional Director
Alliance for Innovation
888-468-6450 Office
480-231-3538 Text
pmuse@transformgov.org
www.transformgov.org

answers.author: Elizabeth Wadle
answers.text:
NACTO released the Urban Street Design Guide this week. Give that a try. Good luck!


NACTO released the Urban Street Design Guide this week. Give that a try. Good luck!

author: Amanda Stratton
text: Are there "best practices" guidelines when determining where to place street furniture in pedestrian areas? Specifically, we are interested in knowing the thought behind how frequently a trash can is placed in these areas.
title: Pedestrian Area Design Guidelines
